default.title: invention
default.definition: The action of inventing something, typically a process or device.
default.contextualMeaning: A newly created product or story, in this case, dried pasta and the Marco Polo narrative.
default.exampleSentence: At that time pasta companies were promoting a new invention, dried pasta, so they came up with a story about Marco Polo to sell more pasta.
default.etymology: From late Middle English, from Latin 'inventio(n-)', from 'invenire' meaning 'to find'.
default.rootsAndAffixes: Root: -vent (to come); Prefix: in- (in, on); Suffix: -ion (act of).

default.title: unspecified
default.definition: Not stated clearly or exactly.
default.contextualMeaning: Referring to a time in the past that is not named or identified.
default.exampleSentence: Here, the phrase at one point or another means at some unspecified time in the past.
default.etymology: From 'un-' (not) + 'specified'.

default.title: idiom
default.definition: A group of words established by usage as having a meaning not deducible from those of the individual words.
default.contextualMeaning: A common phrase with a figurative meaning, specifically 'to push the boundaries'.
default.exampleSentence: And finally, the idiom to push the boundaries means to do things which challenge normal acceptable behaviour.
default.etymology: From late 16th century: from French 'idiome', or via late Latin from Greek 'idiōma' meaning 'private property, peculiar phraseology'.

default.title: boundaries
default.definition: A line that marks the limits of an area; a dividing line.
default.contextualMeaning: The limits of what is considered normal or acceptable behavior, especially in food traditions.
default.exampleSentence: Unlike other Japanese foods, it's OK to push the boundaries.
default.etymology: From Old French 'bodne', from Medieval Latin 'bodina'.

default.title: acceptable
default.definition: Able to be agreed on; suitable.
default.contextualMeaning: Behavior that is considered satisfactory or allowed by social norms.
default.exampleSentence: If you push the boundaries, you act in a way which challenges normal acceptable behaviour.
default.etymology: From late Middle English, from Old French, from 'accepter' (to accept).

default.title: fresh
default.definition: (of food) recently made or obtained; not canned, frozen, or otherwise preserved.
default.contextualMeaning: Noodles made from raw ingredients right before cooking, as opposed to being dried.
default.exampleSentence: Well, some people buy them dried in a packet, others make them fresh from wheat or rice, but there is little doubt that noodles are popular around the world.
default.etymology: From Old English 'fersc', of West Germanic origin.

default.title: popular
default.definition: Liked, admired, or enjoyed by many people or by a particular person or group.
default.contextualMeaning: Widely liked and consumed by people across the globe.
default.exampleSentence: In the 1920s, noodles were popular because they were exotic, meaning foreign, unusual and exciting.
default.etymology: From late Middle English, from Latin 'popularis', from 'populus' meaning 'people'.

default.title: origins
default.definition: The point or place where something begins, arises, or is derived.
default.contextualMeaning: The beginning or source of noodles, believed to be in China.
default.exampleSentence: From their origins, probably somewhere in China, noodle recipes were spread by traders on the ancient Silk Road.
default.etymology: From Old French 'origine', from Latin 'origo', from 'oriri' meaning 'to rise'.

default.title: recipes
default.definition: A set of instructions for preparing a particular dish, including a list of the ingredients required.
default.contextualMeaning: Methods and instructions for making different kinds of noodle dishes.
default.exampleSentence: From their origins, probably somewhere in China, noodle recipes were spread by traders on the ancient Silk Road.
default.etymology: From late Middle English, from Latin 'recipe' meaning 'take!', imperative of 'recipere'.

default.title: spread
default.definition: Extend over a large or increasing area.
default.contextualMeaning: The dissemination or distribution of noodle recipes across different regions.
default.exampleSentence: BBC World Service programme, The Food Chain, investigated how noodles spread from Asia through Europe to America.
default.etymology: From Old English 'sprǣdan', of West Germanic origin.

default.title: traders
default.definition: A person who buys and sells goods, currency, or stocks.
default.contextualMeaning: Merchants who traveled along the Silk Road, carrying goods and culture.
default.exampleSentence: From their origins, probably somewhere in China, noodle recipes were spread by traders on the ancient Silk Road.
default.etymology: From 'trade' + '-er'. 'Trade' from Middle Low German for 'track, course'.

default.title: destination
default.definition: The place to which someone or something is going or being sent.
default.contextualMeaning: Each stop or location along the ancient Silk Road trade route.
default.exampleSentence: At each destination along the road, people gave noodles a twist, adding different flavours and ingredients to create a new dish.
default.etymology: From late Middle English, from Latin 'destinatio(n-)', from 'destinare' meaning 'to make firm, establish'.

default.title: flavour
default.definition: The distinctive taste of a food or drink.
default.contextualMeaning: The specific tastes added to noodles, such as spicy or savory.
default.exampleSentence: As well as different shapes and ingredients, noodles come in many different flavours.
default.etymology: From Old French 'flaor', of unknown origin.

default.title: ingredients
default.definition: Any of the foods or substances that are combined to make a particular dish.
default.contextualMeaning: The various components, like vegetables or meats, added to noodles.
default.exampleSentence: At each destination along the road, people gave noodles a twist, adding different flavours and ingredients to create a new dish.
default.etymology: From late Middle English, from Latin 'ingredient- 'entering', from 'ingredi'.

default.title: varieties
default.definition: A number or range of different things.
default.contextualMeaning: Different types or kinds of noodle dishes that have been created.
default.exampleSentence: In this programme, we'll visit the United States and Japan, two countries which have taken noodles and created exciting new varieties.
default.etymology: From French 'variété' or Latin 'varietas', from 'varius' (diverse).

default.title: investigated
default.definition: Carry out a systematic or formal inquiry to discover and examine the facts of (an incident, allegation, etc.) so as to establish the truth.
default.contextualMeaning: Formally researched and examined the history of how noodles spread.
default.exampleSentence: BBC World Service programme, The Food Chain, investigated how noodles spread from Asia through Europe to America.
default.etymology: From Latin 'investigare', from 'vestigare' meaning 'to track, trace out'.
default.rootsAndAffixes: Prefix: in- (in, on); Root: vestig- (footprint, track).

default.title: uncovered
default.definition: Discover (something previously secret or unknown).
default.contextualMeaning: Found out or revealed a previously unknown and surprising story.
default.exampleSentence: They uncovered a surprising story: that pasta comes from noodles brought back to Italy by Marco Polo in the 13th century.
default.etymology: From 'un-' (not) + 'cover'.

default.title: exotic
default.definition: Originating in or characteristic of a distant foreign country.
default.contextualMeaning: Considered unusual and exciting because it came from a foreign place like China.
default.exampleSentence: In the 1920s, noodles were popular because they were exotic, meaning foreign, unusual and exciting.
default.etymology: From Greek 'exōtikos', from 'exō' meaning 'outside'.

default.title: association
default.definition: A group of people organized for a joint purpose.
default.contextualMeaning: An organization formed by pasta companies to work together for a common goal.
default.exampleSentence: ...and there was a new pasta association in America that wanted to promote the manufacturing of dried pasta.
default.etymology: From medieval Latin 'associatio(n-)', from 'associare' meaning 'to unite'.

default.title: promote
default.definition: Support or actively encourage (a cause, venture, etc.); further the progress of.
default.contextualMeaning: To advertise and encourage the sale and production of a product.
default.exampleSentence: ...and there was a new pasta association in America that wanted to promote the manufacturing of dried pasta.
default.etymology: From late Middle English, from Latin 'promovere', from 'pro-' (forward) + 'movere' (to move).

default.title: manufacturing
default.definition: The making of articles on a large scale using machinery.
default.contextualMeaning: The industrial production of dried pasta.
default.exampleSentence: ...and there was a new pasta association in America that wanted to promote the manufacturing of dried pasta.
default.etymology: From 'manufacture', from French, from Latin 'manu' (by hand) + 'factura' (a working), from 'facere' (to make).

default.title: meaning
default.definition: What is meant by a word, text, concept, or action.
default.contextualMeaning: Used to clarify or define the word 'exotic' in the sentence.
default.exampleSentence: In the 1920s, noodles were popular because they were exotic, meaning foreign, unusual and exciting.
default.etymology: From 'mean' + '-ing'.

default.title: foreign
default.definition: Of, from, in, or characteristic of a country or language other than one's own.
default.contextualMeaning: Coming from another country, which made noodles seem exotic.
default.exampleSentence: In the 1920s, noodles were popular because they were exotic, meaning foreign, unusual and exciting.
default.etymology: From Old French 'forain', based on Latin 'foras' meaning 'out of doors'.

default.title: localise
default.definition: Restrict (something) to a particular place.
default.contextualMeaning: To adapt foreign dishes to suit local Japanese tastes and preferences.
default.exampleSentence: And at one point or another, different chefs decided to localise these dishes.
default.etymology: From 'local' + '-ise'.

default.title: slices
default.definition: A thin, broad piece of food, such as bread, meat, or cake, cut from a larger portion.
default.contextualMeaning: Thin pieces of meat added as toppings to ramen.
default.exampleSentence: By making these tweaks, adding new toppings and slices of beef or chicken, Japanese chefs created the noodle dish we know today as ramen.
default.etymology: From Old French 'esclice', from 'esclicier' (to split).

default.title: gradually
default.definition: In a gradual way; slowly; by degrees.
default.contextualMeaning: Changing and developing slowly over time.
default.exampleSentence: Frank thinks that Japanese ramen continues to evolve – to develop and change gradually in response to new developments and ideas.
default.etymology: From 'gradual' + '-ly'. 'Gradual' from Latin 'gradus' (step).

default.title: response
default.definition: A reaction to something.
default.contextualMeaning: A change or development that happens as a reaction to new ideas.
default.exampleSentence: Frank thinks that Japanese ramen continues to evolve – to develop and change gradually in response to new developments and ideas.
default.etymology: From Latin 'responsum', from 'respondere' (to answer).

default.title: traditional
default.definition: Existing in or as part of a tradition; long-established.
default.contextualMeaning: Foods like sushi that have long-established customs and are less open to change.
default.exampleSentence: Unlike other traditional food such as sushi, modern versions of ramen push the boundaries.
default.etymology: From 'tradition' + '-al'. 'Tradition' from Latin 'traditio(n-)', from 'tradere' (to deliver).
